title: Want to help fight hunger in Boston? Here are 5 ways to do it.
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Massachusetts SNAP cuts affect over a million people, including children, seniors, and those with disabilities.
Greater Boston Food Bank partners with 600 organizations; $3 donation provides two meals.
Volunteer at East Boston Community Soup Kitchen or donate to community fridges and libraries for food security.

title: As injuries linger, Patriots rookie Kyle Williams could be poised for breakout opportunity
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots rookie Kyle Williams may see increased playtime as Kayshon Boutte remains out with a hamstring injury.
Williams has only two catches on six targets this season but could have a breakout opportunity against the Buccaneers.
Offensive coordinator Josh McDaniels and coach Mike Vrabel express confidence in Williams potentially stepping up his role.

title: What songs are on your ‘divorce playlist’?
author: Meredith Goldstein
bullets: Meredith Goldstein discusses the distinct themes of divorce songs in her Love Letters newsletter.
Divorce songs often explore logistics like finances and step-relatives, unlike breakup songs, Goldstein notes.
Lily Allen's recent album about divorce features songs addressing personal experiences and challenges post-marriage.

title: 10 days after their ugliest loss of year, Bruins are looking like a very different team
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Boston Bruins have won five straight games after a previous 7-2 loss to the Ottawa Senators.
Head coach Marco Sturm emphasizes a defensive system that has improved Bruins' penalty kill to 15-for-16 recently.
Key players like Marat Khusnutdinov and Pavel Zacha contributed to victories, showcasing Bruins' depth and adaptability.

title: Did you follow the local news this week? Take our Greater Boston news quiz.
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Boston.com offers a news quiz to test knowledge on current events in Greater Boston.
The quiz covers trending stories and is curated by Boston.com's editor, Peter Chianca.
Peter Chianca has been Boston.com's general assignment editor since 2019.

title: Tripadvisor to cut 20% of staff amid internal restructuring
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Tripadvisor plans to cut 20% of its workforce, affecting around 600 employees, as part of a strategic internal restructure.
The company is merging its Tripadvisor and Viator brands to enhance focus on user experience and integrate AI technologies.
The restructuring includes an $85 million cost-saving program to improve operations, driven in part by investor pressure from Starboard Value.

title: An abandoned tent has spurred a hiking mystery in New Hampshire
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: An abandoned tent was discovered at Valley Way site in New Hampshire's White Mountains on October 26.
Inside the tent were wet gear and food, but no vehicle matched the found car keys with an Apple AirTag.
New Hampshire Fish and Game officials seek the tent's owner through social media without reports of missing hikers.

title: Local obituary: Susan Hurley, 62, former Patriots cheerleader who founded CharityTeams
author: Boston.com Staff
bullets: Susan Hurley, 62, founded CharityTeams, raising $42 million for nonprofits through athletic events like the Boston Marathon.
A former Patriots cheerleader, Susan was married to Boston Marathon Race Director David McGillivray and had two sons.
Susan passed after battling ovarian cancer; her life will be celebrated at Waters Church in Norwood on November 8.

title: Market Basket launches its own beer — here’s where to buy it
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Market Basket partners with Vermont's Zero Gravity Beer to launch 'More For Your Dollar' lager.
The 12-pack costs $12.99 and is available at Market Basket locations in MA, ME, and NH.
The launch coincides with a company transition after CEO Arthur T. Demoulas's departure.

title: As SJC mulls involvement in public defender work stoppage, here’s where things stand
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Massachusetts public defenders initiated a work stoppage in May, leaving over 900 defendants without legal representation.
The Supreme Judicial Court is considering if judges can grant temporary pay raises to resolve the ongoing work stoppage.
State lawmakers approved a 30% pay increase over two years for bar advocates, but unrepresented defendant numbers remain high.
